node.text: Simply collect the arcane water by the magical wellspring behind the gates, take it to the Blueleaf Aspens on the other side and water the trees.

option.optiontext: That's it, there's nothing else I should know?
I see. I wanted to ask something else.
Alright, I'll be back once it's done.

node.text: Nothing relevant that I can think of, no.

option.optiontext: I see. I wanted to ask something else.
Alright, I'll be back once it's done.

node.text: Well, did you water the plants?

option.optiontext: I wanted to ask about something.
Not yet, I'll be back soon.

node.text: Well, did you water the plants?

option.optiontext: I did. You failed to mention the garden would try to kill me for it.
I wanted to ask about something.
I'll be back later.

node.text: What of it? Did I not say that growing the grapes is hard work?

option.optiontext: Whatever. Can I finally have my grapes now?
Why? Why would the garden attack me? What did you have me do?

node.text: Yes, fine. You've proven yourself a worthy friend of Hydrobor, so I will allow you to pick some. They grow quickly so you should find some on the trees now.

option.optiontext: Perfect! Catch you later, master Botanist.
And will I be attacked by angry plants again?

node.text: Don't be so dramatic, I'm sure you handled yourself fine. If you think about it, magic is by its very essence against the natural order - always twisting, changing, transmuting it. It should not come as a surprise that pouring arcane waters on plants might receive something of a violent reaction from nature.

option.optiontext: Right. Can I finally have those grapes now?
Magic opposes nature? I thought some magic works with nature, like healing spells and such.

node.text: Yes, yes, yes, obviously not all the magic is the same. And yes, the druids have lofty notions about using magic only in the ''right way'', so that it works in some symbiotic balance with nature. I'm sure they'd be appalled at the sight of my garden, the bunch of moralizing tree beards. Bah, druidism has been slowly fading out of existence for ages now and the world is better off for it, if you ask me.

option.optiontext: Right. Can I finally have those grapes now?
I think you should have more respect for nature!

node.text: Hah! Aren't you one to preach? You're the one who came to me for managrapes, remember? Do you think a druid could grow such things? Do you think a druid ever would? Of course not! Like the magic that grows them, they are an utterly unnatural fruit. But that doesn't change the fact that they're incredibly useful to us - some even rely on them.
The fruit grows quickly so you should find some on the trees now. Go pick your grapes, hypocrite, and leave me in peace.

option.optiontext: Okay then...
What, will I be attacked by the garden again?

node.text: Don't be ridiculous! Now get out of my hair, I'm busy.

Welcome, traveler - Marissa at your service! If you ever need anything, I mean anything at all in the world - that happens to be common and not exceptionally hard to find - then I'm your woman! No haggling on the prices, mind you.

option.optiontext: I'm looking for something specific - a focusing crystal used by magi and such folk.
Where did you say that inventor has his workshop?
Then let's see your wares.
Doesn't look like you have anything much of value here.
Im here to pick up the books for the college librarian.
Nothing for now.

node.text: Oh, I know the kind you're talking about. I sometimes trade them to those strange people of Hydrobor, but I don't have any in stock right now.

option.optiontext: So I should ask the magi...?

node.text: Well, the magi like to buy them but they ain't the ones who make them. That's the job of special craftsmen, you know? Artisans, inventors and weird people like that.

option.optiontext: Then where do I find one of those?

node.text: As it happens, there's a man who has his workshop in southern Haywind; way down near the old mine, rough neighborhood if you ask me. Anyway, knock the door on the quirky looking building with a tower and everything and ask for Opticus Aluminar.

option.optiontext: Opticus Aluminar, what kind of a name is that?
Alright, thanks.

node.text: Artisans, inventors and weird people like that, did I not say? If you're looking for that focusing crystal, he'll be the one to make it.

option.optiontext: Fine, I'll go see him.

node.text: Well, you know what they say: 'one man's trash is another man's treasure'. I've found I can trade almost anything and I promise to give you a fair price too.

option.optiontext: I'm looking for something specific - a focusing crystal used by magi and such folk.
Then let's see your wares.
Maybe another time.

node.text: Opticus? Look for a quirky looking building with a tower and everything way down in southern Haywind. It's right by that old abandoned mine.

option.optiontext: Let me have a look at your wares before I go.
Alright, thanks.

node.text: Ah yes, here are the books you need. Be careful with them!

option.optiontext: Thank you!

node.text: <color=#9C8C77> *You find the caretaker lying on the ground with a massive wound on his side. He seems to be bleeding heavily and may not last long. Breathing raggedly, the poor man shifts his gaze to you.* </color>
Quite a storm, eh...?<color=#9C8C77> *cough* </color>Must've been that necromancer's doing... blocked the only way in and out...

option.optiontext: Necromancer? Then... you saw what he did, know what I am?
How did you end up like this?
There's no way out?
Can't leave you here like this, is there anything I can do for you?
I need to go, good luck.

node.text: Aye, watched it happen...<color=#9C8C77> *cough* </color>Saw it all from here, yeah...<color=#9C8C77> *cough, cough* </color>
You were dead, alright... but now you walk, like all these other corpses... the others don't seem to talk too much though...

option.optiontext: I don't understand, why raise them all? Thought he was after me.
How did you end up like this?
There really is no other way out?
Can't leave you here like this, is there anything I can do for you?
I need to go, good luck.

node.text: Then... all the dead in sight began crawling out from their graves... our priest always warned, y'know... do not disturb the sleeping souls... nasty deeds cause their remains to stir...

option.optiontext: How did you end up like this anyway?
There really is no other way out?
Can't leave you here like this, is there anything I can do for you?
I need to go, good luck.

node.text: T'was that bloody necromancer... stormed in here like he owned the place... tried askin' what business he had here... Without a word, man plunges a dagger into me, leaves me crawlin' here...

option.optiontext: Then... you saw what he did, know what I am?
And there's really no way out?
Can't leave you here like this, is there anything I can do for you?
I need to go, good luck.

node.text: Afraid so... forest grows so thick around here... 'cept of course... think there's a way through the underground crypts, but...<color=#9C8C77> *cough, cough, cough* </color>

option.optiontext: But what?
Just tell me where to enter these crypts.

node.text: Well... seeing as the dead are all walking up here... those crypts, they must be crawling with 'em...<color=#9C8C77> *cough* </color>Might not be in a friendly mood either...<color=#9C8C77> *cough, cough* </color>

option.optiontext: I'll have to carve my way through then, where do I enter?
You saw the necromancer, what he did to me?
How did you end up like this anyway?
Can't leave you here like this, is there anything I can do for you?
I need to go, good luck.

node.text: There's an entrance right next to the ceremonial hall...<color=#9C8C77> *cough* </color>at the heart of the cemetery...

option.optiontext: You saw the necromancer, what he did to me?
How did you end up like this anyway?
Can't leave you here like this, is there anything I can do for you?
I need to go, good luck.

node.text: Kindness from an undead 'monster'...? Was not expecting such a thing, thank you... you could still save me, I shan't need but a simple healing potion... but I need one quickly, not sure how much longer I can hold on...

option.optiontext: Don't see any potions lying around.

node.text: If you can't find one, it may be possible to make one...<color=#9C8C77> *cough* </color>There's an old alchemy workbench left forgotten in the crypts, I think...

option.optiontext: Wouldn't I need some sort of ingredients?
<color=#9C8C77> *Remind yourself of the ingredients for a healing potion.* </color>
I'll see what I can do.

node.text: Takes a little skill, but it's a fairly simple potion...<color=#9C8C77> *cough* </color>You can extract it from redberries...<color=#9C8C77> *cough* </color>and dandelions... all grow around here plenty...

option.optiontext: I'll see what I can do.

node.text: <color=#9C8C77> *Having dabbled in alchemy in the past, you recall that extracting a single healing potion requires exactly 3 redberries and 5 dandelions.* </color>

option.optiontext: I'll see what I can do.

node.text: Ain't exactly the expert authority on dark magic, y'know... but when that necromancer cast his spell... a lot of power... flashing lights... felt a shockwave pass through the land...
<color=#9C8C77> *The caretaker stares at the sky, barely noticing your presence.* </color>

option.optiontext: Don't die just yet! I brought a potion for you.

node.text: Oh...? Hello... again...

option.optiontext: You don't seem to be doing too well.
I had a few questions...
Just checking you're still alive.

node.text: <color=#9C8C77> *cough* </color>... you don't say...

option.optiontext: About the potion you need...?
You saw the necromancer, what he did to me?
How did you end up like this anyway?
Is there really no other way out of here?
Alright, hang in there.

node.text: Okay, but... I don't think I have much time left...

option.optiontext: About the potion you need...?
You saw the necromancer, what he did to me?
How did you end up like this anyway?
Is there really no other way out of here?
Alright, hang in there.

node.text: Please, a simple healing potion is all I require... If you can't find one, it may be possible to make one...<color=#9C8C77> *cough* </color>There's an old alchemy workbench left forgotten in the crypts, I think...

option.optiontext: Wouldn't I need some sort of ingredients?
<color=#9C8C77> *Remind yourself of the ingredients for a healing potion.* </color>
Had another question...
Alright, hang in there.

node.text: Takes a little skill, but it's a fairly simple potion...<color=#9C8C77> *cough* </color>You can extract it from redberries...<color=#9C8C77> *cough* </color>and dandelions... all grow around here plenty...

option.optiontext: Had another question...
Alright, hang in there.

node.text: <color=#9C8C77> *Having dabbled in alchemy in the past, you recall that extracting a single healing potion requires exactly 3 redberries and 5 dandelions.* </color>

option.optiontext: Had another question...
Alright, hang in there.

node.text: You... you did...? Oh, bless the ancestors!
<color=#9C8C77> *You hand a healing potion to the caretaker, who eagerly gulps it down.* </color>

Truth be told, I wasn't ready to die yet. You may be undead, but I owe you my life, sir! I promise, I won't breathe a word to anyone about what happened to you; I know folk might not be very understanding.

option.optiontext: What will you do now?
I should go, good luck.

node.text: I'll need to rest here awhile and let the potion do its work, but once I've gathered my strength, I can hopefully sneak my way out behind you. Then I'm getting the hell out of here, to Haywind... know some folk there.

option.optiontext: Then I should go, good luck.

node.text: Look for me, if you find yourself in Haywind. Maybe I can properly thank you there.
<color=#9C8C77> *The poor man lies motionless, eyes open with an empty stare toward the sky.* </color>

option.optiontext: <color=#9C8C77> *Close his eyes an mutter a short prayer.* </color>

node.text: <color=#9C8C77> *At least he looks more at peace for now.* </color>
Treat the forest with respect, traveler, and it might respect you back.

option.optiontext: So if a make a prayer to mother nature, I won't be ambushed by a wolf, or a goblin?

node.text: Ah, I know the local hatred for goblins. Yet they too serve their purpose. They protect its sacred places, such as its heart.

option.optiontext: Can you point me to the Temple of Etherlight?
Know anything about the Forest's Heart?

node.text: The what...? You one of 'em treasure seeking nuts? There are some old ruins just east of here, but anybody with half a brain knows to steer clear of those.

option.optiontext: Know anything about the Forest's Heart?

node.text: Eh? Do I look like some tree loving druid? No, didn't think so.

option.optiontext: Can you point me to the Temple of Etherlight?

node.text: Friendly warnin', traveler - been ambushed both by goblins and sentient trees north of here. Not the safest spot to be hunting these days.

option.optiontext: Sounds like an area where the Forest's Heart might be found.
Sentient trees, eh?
Those goblins are real pests, aren't they?
Alright, thanks for the heads up.

node.text: Maybe. All the more reason to steer clear, if you ask me. What's your interest in such things anyways? Don't tell me you're one of them thrill seeking adventurers, maybe chanced to overhear a druid rambling about local myths?

option.optiontext: Only someone looking to pay my respects, I have great admiration for the woodlands.
You know something about it, then?
I don't need to explain myself to you.

node.text: Hm, likewise brother. Well, if you insist, I may know of a way. Fending off a goblin ambush one time, I stumbled upon a little cave northeast of here, right by one of their encampments.

The spiteful little creatures drove me to retreat deeper in, until I eventually came out the other side and... Well, it was there that I discovered it - the Forest's Heart. Like anyone else before then, I'd only heard stories of it...

That there's a secret place of magic hidden somewhere in the forest's depths. But it's not just a place - it's a whole majestic tree spirit. I feared it would be the end of me, but ultimately it opened a path and let me leave unharmed.

option.optiontext: Impressive story, thanks.

node.text: <color=#9C8C77> Ivonna has marked the location of the underground passage on your map. </color>
Hm, probably not more than fanciful stories. Such things are best shared by the campfire with fellow hunters you trust, I think. So, adventurer - you hunt?

option.optiontext: I do.
I have little patience for such things.

node.text: Glad to hear it! The meat from the giant forest snails that grow around here is something of a local delicacy. I'm still a little light on my quota, I could pay you a small share if you bring me 5 pieces.

option.optiontext: Alright, I'll think about it.

node.text: You heard right. Used to be a real rare sight too back when I was a kid. Starting to see more and more of them, and they don't act too friendly either. Times are changing, I guess.

option.optiontext: Those goblins are real pests, aren't they?
Sounds like an area where the Forest's Heart might be found.
Huh, thanks for the heads up.

node.text: Keep safe while hunting, friend. Never know when a goblin's arrow might find your back, not to mention those fearsome sentient trees.

option.optiontext: Been hunting a lot of those forest snails... <color=orange> (5 snail meat) </color>
Got that snail meat you asked for.
Sentient trees, eh?
Those goblins are real pests, aren't they?

node.text: Nice! I'm always happy to take their meat off your hands, if you're willing to settle for a small share of coins.

option.optiontext: Sure thing!
Actually, think I'll hold onto these for now...

node.text: Excellent work, brother! You've earned the coins I promised, but also my respect as a fellow hunter. I wonder, you were curious about the Forest's Heart?
I may have a tale to share... Fending off a goblin ambush one time, I stumbled upon a little cave northeast of here, right by one of their encampments.
You heard right. Used to be a real rare sight too back when I was a kid. Starting to see more and more of them, and they don't act too friendly either. Times are changing, I guess.

option.optiontext: Those goblins are real pests, aren't they?
Been hunting those forest snails... <color=orange> (5 snail meat) </color>
Got that snail meat you asked for.

node.text: Most people seem to think so. I'd settle for leaving them alone, if only they let me hunt in peace. I believe the creatures spread through the forest by digging underground tunnels.

option.optiontext: And sentient trees, eh?
Been hunting those forest snails... <color=orange> (5 snail meat) </color>
Got that snail meat you asked for.

node.text: Most people seem to think so. I'd settle for leaving them alone, if only they left me alone in return. I believe the creatures spread through the forest by digging underground tunnels.

option.optiontext: And sentient trees, eh?
Seems like the right area for finding the Forest's Heart.
Huh, thanks for the heads up.

node.text: Try not to scare the animals when treading the woods. A lot of us hunters out here would appreciate it.

option.optiontext: Been hunting some of those snakes... <color=orange> (2 snake skins) </color>
What do you hunt?
There a lot of hunters out here?
Know anything about the Forest's Heart?
Fair enough.

node.text: Oh, pretty much everything the forest has to offer. But snake skins are something special, though. Tell ya what, I'll offer a share of coins for every 2 you bring me.

option.optiontext: There a lot of hunters out here?
Know anything about the Forest's Heart?
As a matter of fact, been hunting some of those snakes... <color=orange> (2 snake skins) </color>

node.text: A few, yeah. Ivonna's camping a bit northwest from here, I believe. That lady is one tough hunter. Then there's the upstart boy-hunter named Hermes, he oughta be to the northeast.

option.optiontext: What do you hunt?
Know anything about the Forest's Heart?
Been hunting some of those snakes... <color=orange> (2 snake skins) </color>

node.text: <color=#9C8C77> *The old man's ears seem to prick up, his eyes widen.* </color>
You hear it too?! The forest speaks to me all the time. Whispers things to me... The young ones think me a crazy old gramps, but we know better you and I, eh? Ain't that right, eh?!

option.optiontext: Calm down, I just need to know where to find it.
Oh really? What does it whisper?

node.text: Find it...? Find it...?!?! One does not simply *find* it! It's everywhere... and nowhere! Within every shadow of every tree, watching! Always watching...

option.optiontext: Think you've spent too long out in the woods, old man.
Think I should go.

node.text: It tells me things... tells me things about the townsfolk... things they say behind my back... they think I don't know, think I can't hear them... the forest tells me all... hehehe...

option.optiontext: Uhm... any idea where to find it?
Think you've spent too long out in the woods, old man.
Think I should go.

node.text: Bah! I thought you'd understand. But you're just like the townsfolk after all! Ignorant, always laughing, ridiculing what you can't understand! Gah, just... don't talk to me for a while!
Fantastic stuff, fellow hunter. A small share of coins is what I can offer.

option.optiontext: Sure thing!
Actually, think I'll hold onto these for now...

node.text: Hey, I was here first! Find your own hunting spot or whatever!

option.optiontext: Been hunting some of those bears... <color=orange> (3 bear paws) </color>
What do you hunt?
There a lot of hunters out here?
Know anything about the Forest's Heart?

node.text: Oh yeah? Could cut you a sweet deal for those paws or whatever, y'know...

option.optiontext: Sure thing!
Actually, think I'll hold onto these for now...

node.text: Whaddya think, pops? Nothing more prestigious to a hunter than a real bear paw. Shows everyone you're a real hunter, a real man, y'know? Could take 'em off your hands, if you bring me a lot of three, or whatever.

option.optiontext: There a lot of hunters out here?
Know anything about the Forest's Heart?
As it happens, I may be carrying some... <color=orange> (3 bear paws) </color>
Alright, take care kid.
option.actions: NpcChat=Hey> I ain't a kid! Like> whatever gramps...

node.text: Oh yeah, Ehrward's a crazy old gramps camping south of here. Reckon he's lost the plot a long time ago, says some really weird stuff, especially when he gets drunk.
Ivonna's cool though, she's hanging out to the west I think. A real veteran hunter, I reckon. Much better company than Ehrward.

option.optiontext: What do you hunt, then?
Know anything about the Forest's Heart?
Been hunting some of those bears... <color=orange> (3 bear paws) </color>
Alright, take care kid.
option.actions: NpcChat=Hey> I ain't a kid! Like> whatever gramps...

node.text: Um... yeah, like every real hunter knows about that, pssh! But it's like secret stuff, y'know? Can't go around sharing it to just anyone.

option.optiontext: You don't have a clue what I'm talking about, do you?
What do you hunt?
There a lot of hunters out here?
Been hunting some of those bears... <color=orange> (3 bear paws) </color>
Whatever kid, take care.
option.actions: NpcChat=Hey> I ain't a kid! Like> whatever gramps...

node.text: Psssh! Like, whatever! I don't have to prove anything to you man, I know my stuff. Matter of fact, I know more about this forest than most folk! But those are strictly hunter secrets, you gotta be a real good hunter to learn that stuff.

option.optiontext: What do you hunt?
There a lot of hunters out here?
Been hunting some of those bears... <color=orange> (3 bear paws) </color>
Whatever kid, take care.
option.actions: NpcChat=Hey> I ain't a kid! Like> whatever gramps...

node.text: Amid all the trash, a conspicuous note scribbled in poor handwriting catches your eye.

You struggle to make sense of the shoddy letters, but it appears to read: \n\n <color=orange>'Smart inventor man has lot of valuable things in shop, would be shame if something happen to valuable things. Because yous smart, you understand you need to pay lots of gold to protect them valuable things. Bring gold to me in tavern this evening. Or maybe bad things happen to you and stuff.'</color>

The letter is simply signed 'Hubert'. By the looks of things, the inventor didn't take the contents of the letter very seriously. I should find someone who passes for the law around here and tell them what I found.
Yes, pale man, what is it? Be quick about it.

option.optiontext: It's about the inventor - Opticus Aluminar...
Where did you say Hubert likes to camp?
You're the man in charge of upholding the law around here?
I don't like your tone.

node.text: For the hundreth time - no. I cannot clear the quarry below his workshop of all the vagrants, no matter how much I'd like to. The mayor says those people still have rights, whatever that means.

option.optiontext: ... I found his workshop trashed and the man himself missing. I also found a blackmail note signed by someone named Hubert.

node.text: Really? He signed a blackmail note using his own name? Well, I knew he's stupid, but I had no idea just how much. Don't worry, I'll have my men arrest him at the gates next time he shows up. He'll hang above the waters of Aure soon after.

option.optiontext: What about the inventor himself? Aren't you going to rescue him?
You know of this Hubert?

node.text: He's local scum, broadly known as Hubert the Axe, often arrested for fighting at the tavern and garnered something of a reputation for his stupidity and depravity. He's strong as an ox though, and vicious to boot, so he's not to be underestimated.

option.optiontext: What about the inventor himself? Aren't you going to rescue him?

node.text: I don't have the men to spare for a search and rescue effort! There's an entire horde of marauders rampaging on the fields to the west, I need all available hands to keep the city safe. And for all I know that man might be dead already.

option.optiontext: Guess I'll have to go after him myself, then.
Sounds like a tough situation, suppose if nothing can be done...

node.text: <color=#9C8C77> *A whip cracks across your mind, as Gabrius' curse compels you to retrieve the inventor.* </color>

option.optiontext: Agh, I...!

node.text: Are you alright, man?! You look even paler than before, if such a thing was possible.

option.optiontext: I'm fine... Somebody needs to rescue that inventor, so I'll be going after him myself...

node.text: Are you sure? I said he's stupid, but he's also dangerous and not to be underestimated.

option.optiontext: We'll see about that, just tell me where to find him.
How dangerous is he, exactly?

node.text: He's an unusually big man, known to wave a massive battleaxe around, but that's not all... He's said to wear a magical bracelet that can summon a deadly blast of fire.

option.optiontext: Wait, how does a stupid man with a big axe come to carry a magical bracelet?
Just tell me where to find him.

node.text: Well there's a story... Some time ago he was involved in a scuffle with one of those magi of Hydrobor. One night a mage got himself a little too inebriated at a local tavern, they gambled, he bet a magical bracelet and lost...
The man had tried to weasel his way out of it, of course. Things got a bit heated and the next thing anyone knew, Hubert used his axe to part the mage with his bracelet, alongside half of his arm...

option.optiontext: I see, but I still need to know where to find him.

node.text: I've had reports of him camping in the hills southwest of the city. But before you go... I know I said I can't spare anyone, but it doesn't feel right sending you alone either.
I have a recruit whacking at training dummies up the ladder, he'll join you if you ask him. Just try to bring him back alive, would you?

option.optiontext: Alright, thank you Marshal.

node.text: Indeed, Marshal Jaem Harrington at your service, as appointed by the Lord-Mayor in Thornhill himself. I'm tasked with restoring peace and order to this region, since these peasant fools have allowed bandit gangs to fester and run unabated across their lands.

option.optiontext: I wanted to talk about the inventor - Opticus Aluminar...
How is that going for you?
You seem to have the look of a real soldier, unlike most of your men if I'm being frank.

node.text: Are you asking seriously, or have you come here to smirk? I've done what I can, but forming a functioning militia out of these spineless twirps is already a miracle in itself.

At least the criminals aren't free to walk about the town in broad daylight anymore, but if you're going to travel the roads beyond the city walls, I would advise you not to go alone. The fields west of the city have been hit particularly hard.

option.optiontext: I can handle myself.
You seem to have the look of a real soldier, unlike most of your men if I'm being frank.
I wanted to talk about the inventor - Opticus Aluminar...
I see. Goodbye.

node.text: Yes, I've heard that line before. Many a time from men who're now buried with an arrow lodged in their skull. Well, consider yourself warned.

option.optiontext: I wanted to talk about the inventor - Opticus Aluminar...
You seem to have the look of a real soldier, unlike most of your men if I'm being frank.
I see. Goodbye.

node.text: That's because I am; the Lord-Mayor promoted me to this task from the Captain of Thornhill's men-at-arms. A poisoned chalice, though I had no option to refuse. There were rumors the current Lord-Mayor does not appreciate my intolerance for... let's call it corruption.

option.optiontext: A poisoned chalice? Why?
Tell me about the Lord-Mayor.
How's restoring order going for you?
I wanted to talk about the inventor - Opticus Aluminar...
I see. Goodbye.

node.text: I'm not expected to succeed; I'm expected to remain stuck here until the end of my days, as far as the Lord-Mayor is concerned. By the looks of things that may end up being the case. Something about these marauders we're plagued with, they're too... coordinated.

option.optiontext: Tell me about the Lord-Mayor.
How's restoring order going for you?
I wanted to talk about the inventor - Opticus Aluminar...
I see. Goodbye.

node.text: Callum Goldbridge, Mayor of Thornhill, Lord of the Thale, ever since his father displaced the previous ruling family - the Aercrests. Though there are rumors that Aercrest loyalists still reside in Morningfade, but I wouldn't know of it.

option.optiontext: An Aercrest should rule Imberthale...
You said this posting was a poisoned chalice, why?
How's restoring order going for you?
I wanted to talk about the inventor - Opticus Aluminar...
I see. Goodbye.

node.text: I'd keep that kind of talk to yourself. I may not be the Lord-Mayor's most loyal servant, but I'm no traitor either.

option.optiontext: You said this posting was a poisoned chalice, why?
How's restoring order going for you?
I wanted to talk about the inventor - Opticus Aluminar...
I see. Goodbye.

node.text: And I don't like people who waste my time. Was there something you actually wanted to discuss, or should I have my men throw you out?

option.optiontext: I wanted to talk about the inventor - Opticus Aluminar...
Where did you say Hubert likes to camp?
You're the man in charge of upholding the law around here?
I'll go.

node.text: I've heard reports that he likes to set up camp in the hills southwest of the city. Remember not to underestimate him.

option.optiontext: You said one of your men might help me?
You're the man in charge of upholding the law around here?
I'll be going then.

node.text: Used to be a silver mine, but dried up what must be a century ago. Now it's mostly used as shelter by all sorts of lowlifes. You'll find it south of town.

option.optiontext: You said one of your men might help me?
Okay, I'll be going then.

node.text: Yeah, I left him training on the roof. He's still a bit wet behind the ears, so please try not to get him killed.

option.optiontext: You're the man in charge of upholding the law around here?
I'll be going then.

node.text: I like leather. Do you like leather?

option.optiontext: Umm... Yes.
Not today.

node.text: Thought so.

option.optiontext: Let's see what you have then.
So who are you?
I'll just go now.
A hunter who sells leather - let's see what you've got.
No, I mean what's your name?
Well, see you around Hunter.

node.text: Hunter. My name's Hunter.

option.optiontext: Oh, sorry. Let's just see what you sell then.
Oh. Ooooh. Right. I see now.
Ah, right. Well, goodbye Hunter.
Let's just see what you sell then.
You don't talk much, do you?
I'll just go now.
Right. Let's see about that leather then.
Okay. Good talk. See you later.

node.text: Who is it? You people ought to know my eyesight isn't what it used to be.

option.optiontext: You don't know me - I'm Rothar.
It's me - Rothar.

node.text: Oh, a newcomer? Welcome, dear! Used to be a rare thing in these parts but now it seems like every other person who steps through my door. What can old Mareya do for you?

option.optiontext: I'm looking for a healer.
How old are you then?
Nothing for now.

node.text: That's what I do. Stay still and let me have a look at you... Okay... even my ageing eyes can see you need more color on those cheeks - I recommend redberries.

Hah, that would be telling! Though I might have gained a few extra years from my healing herbs over the decades, who knows. I still remember when Haywind was but a small village, the magi of Hydrobor only a distant tale and the land still ruled by an Aercrest.

option.optiontext: I'm looking for a healer.
Interesting, but I must go.

node.text: Ah, I remember you Rothar! My eyes may have failed me, but not my memory thankfully. What can old Mareya do for you?

option.optiontext: I'm looking for a healer.
How old are you then?
Nothing for now.

node.text: You again? You enjoy bothering me, don't you? Can't you see I'm busy trying to infuse arcane energies into a Moonshade Leaf?

option.optiontext: You what?
So why did plants suddenly spring to life and attack me when I was trying to water the Blueleaf Aspens?
What can you tell me about your gardens?
I'll leave you to it then.

node.text: A task the mere mention of which flies right past the heads of simpletons like yourself.

option.optiontext: No, why would you try to infuse Moonshade Leaf with the arcane?
I'll just go.

node.text: Oh why do I ever do anything? How do you think the Blueleaf Aspen and its managrapes were discovered? Through meticulous research of course, and that's what I'm trying to carry out here. But I keep getting interrupted by fools like you!

option.optiontext: I see. But I did actually want to ask you something.
Oh, sorry. I'll just go then.

node.text: You're still left thinking about that? I would have thought it's obvious; magic is by its very essence against the natural order - always twisting, changing, transmuting it. It should not come as a surprise that pouring arcane waters on plants might receive something of a violent reaction from nature.

option.optiontext: Magic opposes nature? I thought some magic works with nature, like healing spells and such.
That's great. There's something else I wanted to ask.

node.text: Yes, yes, yes, obviously not all the magic is the same. And yes, the druids have lofty notions about using magic only in the ''right way'', so that it works in some symbiotic balance with nature. I'm sure they'd be appalled at the sight of my garden, the bunch of moralizing tree beards. Bah, druidism has been slowly fading out of existence for ages now and the world is better off for it, if you ask me.

option.optiontext: C'mon, I think you should respect nature a little!
Yeah, druids are lame.
That's great. There's something else I wanted to ask.

node.text: Hah! Aren't you one to preach? You're the one who came to me for managrapes, remember? Do you think a druid could grow such things? Do you think a druid ever would? Of course not! Like the magic that grows them, they are an utterly unnatural fruit. But that doesn't change the fact that they're incredibly useful to us - some even rely on them.

option.optiontext: I suppose that's fair. I had another question.
Okay, well. Goodbye.

node.text: Have you ever met a druid? Yeah, I did not think so. Druids aren't ''lame'', they are a nuisance and some of them are downright dangerous. If you meet any, I advice you keep your distance.

option.optiontext: Oh, okay. I had another question.
Right, well. Goodbye.

node.text: Ah, well the centerpiece behind the gates is an Arcane Everbloom. A very small tree in nature, but over the years I've unlocked its true potential. Powerful magical currents flow through that one, in service of the Academy.

option.optiontext: That's great. There's something else I wanted to ask.

node.text: Past the Arcane Everbloom, several Blueleaf Aspens. They bear the fruit that is every wizard's best friend - Managrapes. Only someone with my set of skills could ever hope to successfully grow these maginificent trees.

option.optiontext: What makes managrapes so special anyways?
That's great. There's something else I wanted to ask.

node.text: The southern section of the gardens is a leisurely park, nothing too exceptional grows there. Though, to my pride, I have managed to attract some faes into it. Faes are very picky about where they choose to live, you know.

option.optiontext: That's great. There's something else I wanted to ask.
Okay, I'll be going now.

node.text: What do you think? Some foods are known to help connect with the realms of magic but nothing quite does it like managrapes. They aid in recovering mana but more importantly they increase a spell's potency.

option.optiontext: I see, please continue.
That's great. There's something else I wanted to ask.
So why did plants suddenly spring to life and attack me when I was trying to water the Blueleaf Aspens?
What can you tell me about your gardens?
Nevermind, good talk. See you later.

node.text: Oi! We were here first an' we ain't in the mood to share! Find yer own shelter!

option.optiontext: I don't suppose there's any way I can talk you into leaving?
I'm afraid you picked the wrong shack for the evening, lads.
Alright, I hear you.

node.text: I warn ya! I've killed a man, I have! I ain't messin' about!

option.optiontext: That's the way it is, then.

node.text: Shorei na qherizeh, Tasharmin?

option.optiontext: I can't understand you...

node.text: <color=#9C8C77> *The apparition stares at you in silence for a moment.* </color>
It does not speak with the words of the Masters. It speaks with the tongue of a subject, but corrupted. It arrives before the Zatrin and is understood. It may speak.

option.optiontext: I seek the Temple of Etherlight.
Zatrin? Is that your name.
The Masters? Who were they?

node.text: It has arrived before the Zatrin.

option.optiontext: Who were your Masters?
I seek the Temple of Etherlight.

node.text: The Qaeshtar. The ones who command Iera Qae'lesh. The ones who rule these lands and all others.

option.optiontext: If that's so, then where are they?
Zatrin? Is that your name.
I seek the Temple of Etherlight.

node.text: The Zatrin observes the skies; the sun has slept 412 316 times since one of the Masters last sought knowledge here. The Zatrin attends its duty and awaits the Masters' return.

option.optiontext: Zatrin? Is that your name.
I seek the Temple of Etherlight.

node.text: It speaks as a subject, yet it seeks to bask in the glory of Ahran'yi Etriem. Is it worthy? Ta'Irek will be the judge of that...

option.optiontext: The what...?

node.text: The Great Temple overlooks these lands on a hill surrounded by the great trees, to the north... But it shall find the Great Temple sealed by its guardian. Only if Ta'Irek deems it worthy, may it pass...

option.optiontext: But Worthy how exactly...?

node.text: Hey, stay back you stupid zombie! Any closer and I'll stab ya!

option.optiontext: Calm down, I'm not a zombie.

node.text: Oh... ya ain't? Ya sure? Cause ya look really pale and all... Well, shiet, guess it's nice I ain't the only living person left 'round 'ere. Now, I dunno about you but I'll just stay nice and quiet back 'ere and wait for them zombos to crawl back into their graves, alright?

option.optiontext: What are you doing here?
Suit yourself.

node.text: Ah, ya know... I ain't lootin' graves or anything, if that's what yer thinking! I just pick up things, y'know. Like stuff people maybe lost or misplaced... and I give it back to them! For a small finder's fee, o'course.

option.optiontext: I wonder if you 'found' something I misplaced...
Of course...

node.text: Keep quiet...! Wouldn't want any of them zombos hearing us chatter.

option.optiontext: I wonder if you've 'found' something I misplaced...
What are you doing here?

node.text: Ey! If yer lookin' for, erm... recycled goods, I'll give you a good deal.

option.optiontext: Let's see what you have, then.
No thanks.

node.text: C'mon, Anders! Quit moaning, I gotta get to Bootlegger's.
Euugh... aaaaaghhh...

option.optiontext: What's going on?

node.text: This idiot here got bitten by way to many swamp insects, at least that's what I think he said somewhere between all his howling.

option.optiontext: I need to get across, deeper into the swamp.
I see, good luck I guess.

node.text: You and me both, but Anders here refuses to move his buttocks. He's what - spent his entire life around here? Now he gets caught by a rookie mistake like letting a swarm of bloodsuckers catch him, ridiculous.
Aghhhh... me skin's aflame...

option.optiontext: Can't we just take the boat ourselves?
There must be something to help him.

node.text: You don't know this place very well, do you? Anders knows which ways you can go to avoid getting crushed by the swamp devourer's tentacles. Without someone like him, you're stepping into a death trap.

option.optiontext: What's the swamp devourer?
There must be something to help him.

node.text: Hell if I know, not sure anyone does really. The thing must reside somewhere underground, because all anyone sees up above are its tentacles. Don't know about you, but personally I'm not too fussed about meeting that creature up close.

option.optiontext: There must be something to help him.

node.text: Hm... well, I suppose we could slather a bunch of swamp goop on his skin. It's pretty foul stuff, but I recall it's a proven trick.
No goop... no goop! ...just get me... erhmmm... beer...! enough beer to make me numb...!

option.optiontext: I happen to be carrying goop<color=#9C8C77> (3x) </color>.
I happen to be carrying beer<color=#9C8C77> (3x) </color>.
What's this goop?
I'll see what I can do.

node.text: Let's slather him up. Stay still Anders, and if you open your mouth to complain, that's where I'll stuff the goop.
<color=#9C8C77> *scoffs* </color> Not sure how safe I'll feel in a boat steered by a drunk.
yesss... give it 'ere...
Oh it's all around the swamp, has a bit of a will of its own. Stuff crawls out from whatever holes and tries to strangle you. Usually stops wriggling though, after you beat it hard enough.

option.optiontext: I happen to have found some already<color=#9C8C77> (3x) </color>.
I happen to be carrying beer<color=#9C8C77> (3x) </color>.
I'll see what I can do.

node.text: Okay, cool...
Oh, it's you again. We're still here, Anders is still the same.

option.optiontext: I bring some of that swamp goop.<color=#9C8C77> (3x) </color>
Alright, I bring gifts of beer.<color=#9C8C77> (3x) </color>
What's the matter with him again?

node.text: <color=#9C8C77> *The ferryman whimpers to himself without looking up.* </color>

option.optiontext: I bring some of that swamp goop. (3x)
Alright, I bring gifts of beer. (3x)
What's the matter with him again?

node.text: This idiot here got bitten by way to many swamp insects, at least that's what I think he said in between all that howling. He's what, spent his entire life around here and gets caught by a rookie error like letting a swarm of bloodsuckers catch him?
Aghhhh... me skin's aflame...
We could slather a bunch of swamp goop on his skin. It's pretty foul stuff, but I recall it's a proven trick.

option.optiontext: Pour me a pint, would you?
I'm looking for a way into Thornhill Dungeons.
Nice place you have here.

node.text: You tryin'a jest? How 'bout you order a beer like everyone else, or take yer leave.

option.optiontext: I'll just have a beer then.
I'm looking for a way into Thornhill Dungeons.
I'll just go.

node.text: Can't a man drink in peace...?

option.optiontext: How about this round's on me? <color=#9C8C77> (offer beer) </color>
Mind if I join you?
I'll leave you to it.

node.text: Yeah, I do.

option.optiontext: Oh, okay.

node.text: That's what I like to hear! I guess you're alright mate.

option.optiontext: Heard someone managed to escape Thornhill Dungeons, got any idea how?
I'll leave you to it.

node.text: Good to see you again, mate. How about we have a drink?

option.optiontext: This round's on me.
Another time.

node.text: That's what I like to hear mate! Cheers!

option.optiontext: Heard someone managed to escape Thornhill Dungeons, got any idea how?
I'll leave you to it.

node.text: Come in, come in, potential customer! Let's discuss your needs and I'm sure we can arrive at a solution. Just a few ground rules first; no names, I don't tell you mine, you don't tell me yours, and importantly - never ask what's in the potion.

option.optiontext: Sounds reasonable.

node.text: I don't want to know what the job is, so when asked, I don't have to lie. Just be assured, the tools you need can be found here.

option.optiontext: Let's take a look.

node.text: The streets of Thornhill can get dangerous, mate. You sure you're armed well enough? I got some good variety here, but I always recommend the heaviest hammer. Bonk them unga bunga style, y'know? That's what I do.

option.optiontext: I'll take a look.

node.text: Please, talk some sense into my stubborn husband! He's no soldier, yet he insists on fighting those bandit marauders who've surrounded our home!

My wife's afeared that I'll lose my life. Yet if I do nothing, we are all sure to perish! Everyone here knows about Baronsgreene - the village that surrendered without a fight - and the bandits pillaged and razed it to the ground!
Just look at him! Off to fight the bandits in soft wool farmer's clothing. He'll only get himself killed!

option.optiontext: True, he should at least wear some armor...
Alas, it is a man's duty...

node.text: Yet I am no magician either, I cannot simply wave my hands and conjure an armor no matter how much I'd like to!

option.optiontext: Perhaps something can be done about that.<color=green> *Offer simple Copper Armor* </color>

node.text: Oh...! Ancestors bless your kindness, traveler! You just may have saved his poor life!

option.optiontext: Good luck out there!

node.text: My brother tells me you're the one to thank for saving us from impending doom. Personally, I can't wait to get the loom up and running again! How about it, 'pale friend'? Up for some real tailoring?

option.optiontext: I'm more interested in seeing what the Estate has in store...
How does your loom work?
Maybe later.

node.text: First off, you'll need to feed wool into the machine to keep it running. For that, grab shears from the table over there and get ready to handle our wooly sheep, specially bred over generations for extra fluffiness!

option.optiontext: Let me see what the Estate has in store...
I've heard enough...

node.text: Their wool goes into the hopper and is refined into threads. Now keep an eye on that refiner - it has a habit of breaking down every now and then. Use a hammer to bang it back in order if it does.

option.optiontext: Let me see what the Estate has in store...
I've heard enough...

node.text: Next comes choosing the dye from the shelf. I tend to set the machine to display whichever color of clothing we most need at any given time, so try to maintain the correct dye bottle in the holder for best results! Don't sweat it too much though - all clothes are valuable.

option.optiontext: Let me see what the Estate has in store...
I've heard enough...

node.text: Once the clothes emerge, the last step is to pack them into the crates in the corner over there. Help us keep the machine running and I'll be sure to find ways to reward your efforts, alright?

option.optiontext: Let me see what the Estate has in store...
Sounds great.

node.text: You've come to a place of darkness.

option.optiontext: A druid, here?
A place of darkness?
I'm looking for a monster called Mudclaw.
I'm going to leave now.

node.text: Why not? There is much to observe here, much that can be learnt. One might instead ask, why does a creature of death walk in the cave of verdant life, hm?

option.optiontext: I'll take that as a rhetorical question.
You called this a place of darkness?
I'm looking for a monster called Mudclaw.
I'm going to leave now.

node.text: Yes, I meant it literally. I hope for your sake you brought light. I have seen people of the village come here sometimes, seeking adventure. They found only darkness, and the dark kept them.

option.optiontext: Why is a druid here?
I'm looking for a monster called Mudclaw.
I'm going to leave now.

node.text: It was meant as such. Like here in this cave, there is a darkness within you. But your darkness comes from a different realm, not the concern of druids.

option.optiontext: This is a place of darkness?
I'm looking for a monster called Mudclaw.
I'm going to leave now.

node.text: So you are, but will you return? Hmm...
That you are. It is here.

option.optiontext: ...know anything about it?
You said this is a place of darkness?
So why is a druid here?
I'm going to leave now.

node.text: I do, but nothing that interests you. You only seek its demise. Perhaps it is correct, if you should vanquish it. Perhaps it is to bring balance. But it will also leave a void...

option.optiontext: You said this is a place of darkness?
So why is a druid here?
I'm going to leave now.

node.text: Ah, the very winds of destiny must've guided you to my realm of potions and enigmas! Each vial here contains a drop of the universe. How may the cosmos serve you today?

option.optiontext: Are you feeling alright, Miss?
What can you tell me about Grainwater?
Any advice about the woods?
Tell me about your tonics.

node.text: Oh, my celestial concoctions! Crafted under the watchful gaze of moon and stars, with herbs kissed by the first light of dawn. Their powers range from rejuvenating the weary to singing lullabies to the restless. Tempted to try?

option.optiontext: Sure, why not.
What can you tell me about Grainwater?
Any advice about the woods?
Are you feeling alright, Miss?

node.text: Grainwater! Where the very air dances with merriment, and every pint holds a story. The villagers, ah, they are symphonies in human form, each adding their note to the grand song of life!

option.optiontext: Any advice about the woods?
Are you feeling alright, Miss?
Tell me about your tonics.

node.text: The woods, they are ancient whisperers, echoing tales from eons past. Yes, wolves reside there, guardians of the old secrets. Tread with respect and they might just let you pass. But for added measure, perhaps a tonic for courage?

option.optiontext: What can you tell me about Grainwater?
Are you feeling alright, Miss?
Tell me about your tonics.

node.text: Ah, dear traveler! Worry not, for my spirit is as vibrant as the cosmos itself. But thank you for asking. It's not every day someone inquires about the well-being of a cosmic tonic brewer.

option.optiontext: What can you tell me about Grainwater?
Any advice about the woods?
Tell me about your tonics.

node.text: Halt! The city's under temporary lockdown! There'll be no one entering the city at this time, so best you move along!

option.optiontext: Why, what's going on?

node.text: The Lord Mayor's putting down a riot, peasants are getting uppity. They'll learn their place soon enough. But in the meantime, the gates are staying closed!

option.optiontext: What are they rioting about?

node.text: A plague recently swept the city, a lot of people died and I guess folk are feeling angry. What was the Lord Mayor supposed to do about it anyway? They'll get over it, but they do need to be reminded of their place! They're getting too many ideas about 'poverty' and 'harsh conditions' now, we'll need to take a firm hand with them.
<color=#9C8C77>*I may be able to enter the city at a later point. For now, somewhere at the back of my mind, Gabrius beckons me to get on with his orders.*</color>

My wife continuously tells me that I know nothing. But I do know some things. I know quite a lot in fact. Seeing as you've been approved by the Headmaster for learning, I'm willing to share my knowledge.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
Are you a blademaster?

node.text: I own no fancy titles, nor do I boast about brave adventures and exploits. I started out as a humble blacksmith's son, wielding different weapons in hand from a young age, day after day, every day... One day a traveler took interest in my talent, asked me to leave my village to become his apprentice. That was the beginning of a story, to be told at a different time.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?

node.text: Aidan Strongbow, at your service! I do not mean to boast, but you're speaking to the Champion of Imberthale's Archery Contest for six years running. It's no easy feat, you know...

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
Ah yes, I won that contest once upon a time myself...
Sure you're not just full of yourself?

node.text: Ah, haha! Highly unlikely! I'm sure I'd know you if that was the case. I know all master archers in these lands, and I'm the best. Really don't mean to boast, but there it is.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?

node.text: Haha, of course not! I said I don't mean to boast, didn't I? But really, I know all master archers in these lands, and the simple truth is, well... that I'm just the best there is.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?

node.text: I'm glad you approach us here at the Master's Academy about tutoring in magic, instead of those Hydrobor upstarts. Thornhill has a long line of capable sorcerers. I, for example, was taught by the revered Master Wizard Tyrhen Hail himself.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
You have something against the Hydrobor Academy?

node.text: I just think we did quite well here in Thornhill long before they came. This wasn't a magically backward place, ever, okay?! It just makes me so angry that some people think the Hydrobor people are the first real magi in these lands.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
Uh, okay.

node.text: I was once tasked with escorting a lord's caravan, when a group of bandits ambushed us. There were perhaps six of them, but I beat them off using a stick I'd picked from the woods earlier that day. Care to know how?

option.optiontext: I care more about what you can teach me.
What do you have for sale?
Fine, do tell.

node.text: Hah! Well have you had a look at me? Their scrubby little bows and rusted daggers couldn't touch me - easiest fight of my life. Take my lessons to heart and you could be like me.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
I see.

node.npcName: Kathleen Collingwood, Master of the Woods
node.text: Ah, how I miss the woods sometimes. I don't think I was born for city life. But it is comfortable, I'll give it that, and I am getting older.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
You miss living in the woods...?

node.npcName: Kathleen Collingwood, Master of the Woods
node.text: Oh yes, as a young enthusiastic explorer, I was lived among the wildfolk of Phalean Woodlands. In their society the men are druidic caregivers, while the women are fierce hunters and warriors. Quite the adventure, I'll tell you that.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
I see.

node.npcName: Arnold S.F. Ustinov, Master of Fishing
node.text: Anyone can make a simple rod and push themselves onto water in a leaky boat. But have you considered what it takes to really master fishing? It is a form of art - I'm an artist and the water is my canvas!

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
Um... got any fishing stories to share?

node.npcName: Arnold S.F. Ustinov, Master of Fishing
node.text: Stories...? My man, every time I go upon water becomes a story, a real adventure! The preparation, the planning... waiting for the exact right moment, when the stars and winds align... the custom, handcrafted gear packed and ready... You shall need to adopt a whole new view on fishing, if you mean to become near as good as I.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?

node.npcName: Gregory V. Mildert, Master of Mines
node.text: Already as a young child I took an interest in rocks. My peers did not understand, they bullied me... called me dumb as a rock! Ever since then I've devoted my entire life to proving one thing, and one thing only - rocks are not dumb, okay?!

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
They aren't...? I mean, what makes you think that?

node.npcName: Gregory V. Mildert, Master of Mines
node.text: Why, they're all around us and there are so many of them! We cannot ever possibly know all there is to know about rocks! If we think we know, along comes a new rock! And we rely on them too, we build our castles from rocks... ever think about that?

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
Can't say I have too much.

node.npcName: Ser Alan Castle, Master of the Forge
node.text: Yes, I'm a noble and I forge metal, what of it? I hope you don't think it's beneath me. If you ask me, it's the most valuable talent in existence - entire kingdoms have been forged by their blacksmiths - and I'm here to perfect that knowledge.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
A nobleman, really?

node.npcName: Ser Alan Castle, Master of the Forge
node.text: Yes, this happens every time! Everyone always wants to know all about my nobility! Well, I am the little cousin of the husband of the sister of the wife of a real baron in Arbothale, Melloria. Who was very unkindly usurped by one of his cousins, so he lives here in exile, but we don't talk about that.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
Oh, okay.

node.text: Welcome, my dear apprentice. welcome! Don't be shy now, here I can teach you to turn fabrics into dreams and legends alike. Whether it be fanciest silks or rarest of leather that calls to you, with my knowledge we'll have you creating wonders.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
What wonders have you ever created?

node.text: I once had the great honor of working on a cloak for the Queen of Elhea herself. They had captured a very real phoenix, the cloak was to be made of its feathers. A masterpiece that took years to complete, not least for waiting the phoenix to grow enough feathers, it has made the Queen incredibly famous to this day!

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?

node.npcName: Lady Hildbede Saint, Master of Crafting
node.text: The Headmaster's told us that we are to share our knowledge with you. You should know, I don't accept any nonsense from my students. Only the strictest discipline can achieve the highest results of learning.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
Is that how you were taught?

node.npcName: Lady Hildbede Saint, Master of Crafting
node.text: I carved idols and effigies as a Sister in the Monastery of Havenport in lands far south. The Abbess was a hard woman; anything less than perfection and I would have to start over. One day I met a fancy traveler and took off with him, but my woodcarving talents stayed with me.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?

node.text: Mesmerizing, aren't they? Flowers I mean. Oftentimes people take them for granted, overlook them or underestimate them. Sometimes they have the power to heal the most grievous of wounds... or instead they may have the power to kill.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
Who are you again?

node.text: Oh, my name's Leila. I was the Wise Woman in the village near the swamp to the east. I had to create most peculiar salves and ointments for the wounds and diseases people would often catch venturing into the swamp. Some of the plants that grow there have very unique powers also.

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
I see.

node.text: I was the Lord Mayor's personal chef up there in Castle Murk for a while. He was a very mean man though, so one day I took off. I'm glad the Academy took me in. I've heard rumors the Lord Mayor's new chef isn't nearly as good, which is making his mood even more foul...

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
Could've tried poisoning his food...

node.text: <color=#9C8C77>*Gasp*</color>! I'll have you know that's very much against my character and ethics as a Master Chef! My creations nourish and restore people!

option.optiontext: What can you teach me?
What do you have for sale?
As you say.

node.text: Gotta be somebody that keeps this outpost running, and that'd be me. I mean, what would these fools ever do if they couldn't buy their supplies from me? Wish they'd keep that in mind whenever they talk to me.

option.optiontext: Spare me the lecture and show me what you're selling.
A village of outlaws and all sorts of shady people? I'm surprised they don't just rob you blind.

node.text: Ah yeah, well... I suppose they could, and those smuggler people next door have definitely insinuated as much. But truth is they know if they do that, no more shopkeeper in the village - no more future supplies. It don't stop them from trash-talking to me every chance they get though.

option.optiontext: What do you have in stock?
I should go.

node.text: Ah, hello there! Welcome to my tavern, I'll serve you with regular beer if you'd like. But as a bit of a brew enthusiast, I'm also known for my very own special beer recipe, featuring a very secret ingredient, just so you know!\n\n<color=#9C8C77>*The bartender gives you a friendly wink.*</color>

option.optiontext: A regular pint will do, thanks...
Don't tell me it's chili powder...
Yeah, maybe later.

node.text: Ah, haha! Good guess, but no - that's my cousin's secret recipe though. Between the two of us, my secret ingredient is far, far more innovative, if I do say so myself. It's why I came to this rather rough neighborhood in fact, as it grows here aplenty.

option.optiontext: Come on, now you've just got to tell me.
How about you just pour me a normal pint, thanks.
I'm good for now, maybe later.

node.text:
Hahaha, alright, alright, alright... you ready? Here comes...

<color=#9C8C77>*The bartender leans in closer and speaks in hushed tones for dramatic effect...*</color>

It's mushrooms...! Dried, ground mushrooms, Mushroom-P, yo! Genius, right? Can you believe it?

option.optiontext: I'd rather not, sounds utterly disgusting...
Heavens sake, just pour me a regular pint.
That's it, I'm leaving.

node.text: Hey come on, now. It's not like anyone's ever complained about it! Well, not since I had to flee Thornhill anyway, when the guards found out what I was putting in the beer...

option.optiontext: I'll buy a beer, just keep your mushrooms well away from it.
Lucky for you, I doubt this crowd much cares about taste...

node.text: There's only one rule on this village - don't ever step on my toes. Respect that and we'll get along just fine.

option.optiontext: Why's that, are you the village queen?
Fair enough.

node.text: You're being sarcastic, but it's not far from the truth. Earned myself the nickname 'Smuggler Queen' among these folk. And trust me, it's not just idle talk. I'm the only real authority in this place.

option.optiontext: Good to know.

node.text: Have no fear over my companion, Arktosa. She is far more intelligent and insightful a bear than some of her more feral cousins.

option.optiontext: I take it you're a druid.

node.text: The Ebongreen Circle is my family. My kind often takes shelter in the deep forests south, what has been named the Mistywood, and far to the north also. We make our home where nature is left undisturbed. Sadly, there are forces that ever keep shrinking such lands.

option.optiontext: Sounds like you're far from home, then.
I see.

node.text: True, we traveled here from the north. I asked Arktosa to accompany me on this journey, though I knew it would takes us to hostile lands. I've long known about this place, it is a stain on true nature - a travesty.

option.optiontext: How so?
As you say.

node.text: These marshlands have suffered from centuries of distortion through magic. The plants grow too wild and free, consuming everything. There's no wildlife to keep them in check, instead only monsters prowl here. Monsters that were men, once, but have long since forgotten what that meant.

Some grew reptilian skins and a hunger for human flesh, others twisted and spineless crawl within the undergrowth, seeking to strangle living things. And worst of them all, hidden below ground, a being of relentless hunger that grew long, evil tentacles with which to devour any and all beings it can only reach.

I do not know how to help these lands, or even if they can be helped. But we druids have a responsibility to all nature, and it especially ought to extend to lands that are sick and suffer. I thought remaining within our sheltered sanctuaries seems cowardly, though it has increasingly become the choice my kind falls back on.

option.optiontext: Interesting, good luck in your mission.

node.text: Ain't got a bed for you, pale face. Got a silly druid and a pair of wannabe pirates clogging up the place as is. Just about had enough of their nonsense, but s'long as they got coin to pay for their stay...

option.optiontext: Pirates, really?
A druid is your guest?
I see.

node.text: Just about any fool thinks they can be a pirate these days. All they need is some light theft and a stinky old barge, only these maestros managed to sink even that and now they won't shut up about it!

option.optiontext: A druid is your guest?
I see.

node.text: Aye, and brought a bear with him - a real live bear! Told him straight up, the bear has no business coming into my house. But that don't stop the thing from prowling around, making a whole lot of racket, even at night!

option.optiontext: Pirates, really?
I see.

node.text: Hey you. We were on the boat together, in case you forgot or something. I'm Mona Lizz, by the way.

option.optiontext: That your real name?
I'm leaving.

node.text: Why, you don't think it sounds like a real name? Pfff, fine, you got me. But I'm not telling you my real name. I'm an aristocrat's daughter from Thornhill. Loving dear old papa's probably looking for me...

All he wants is for me to wear fancy dresses, attend balls and get married with someone I don't care about, the sooner the better. Can you imagine - me?! Told the old man I wanna chase adventure, like heroes from stories I read as a child. He just laughed and called me a silly girl. So I left.

option.optiontext: Why come here?
Good for you.

node.text: Oh, I've drifted here and there for some time now, got to know places, had small adventures... mostly boring adventures. Then I read about treasures of all kind lost in the swamp, left behind by other brave adventurers who perished here, you know?

I mean to find some! Er, just as soon as I know where to look... was hoping to overhear some juicy secret in the tavern actually. I've been this way a few times, thing here is you never know who's gonna pop through the door for a drink, and the things they know...

option.optiontext: I see, good luck with that.

node.text: Shshhashrr shkhrashsh ssss shihsskrrhh?\n\n<color=#9C8C77>*This curious lizard doesn't seem hostile, unlike the rest of his kind. Instead he appears to be attempting to communicate, hissing and gesturing in a deliberate way.*</color>

option.optiontext: Errr... shhh shhh shhhhhh?
Afraid I just can't understand you...

node.text: <color=#9C8C77>*The lizard waves his arm in dismissive frustration...*</color>\n\nShrrrasshhh...!

option.optiontext: I should go...

node.text: You are welcome in my home, so long as you have come in peace. Sometimes I receive visitors from my old mountain home. They bring with them old hatreds. Always I must bury them afterwards.

option.optiontext: Mountain home?
You're a wanted man?

node.text: Mountains of the White Eagle, have you heard of them? A beautiful place, far away from here. White mountain tops above, fertile valleys below... alas, I am no longer welcome there.

option.optiontext: You're a wanted man?
Sorry to hear that.

node.text: I was a proud warrior and the loyal servant of one Lord. Tragically, I was not able to protect him, he was murdered by another - a tyrant. I could not stay, but the tyrant did not forget about me. Each time his men found me, I moved further away. I have moved many times now, and come far.

option.optiontext: Where was your mountain home?

node.text: If you need someone roughed up, you gotta pay good coin in advance, understand?

option.optiontext: I'm looking for a skilled herbalist with knowledge of bewitched plants...
What's the village good for?

node.text: Whaddya think, eh? Mostly this is a hideout for interesting characters, and the only shelter in this deadly swamp in truth. You can find basic supplies, just talk to Farraway in the central hut, or grab a beer at the tavern.

There's a lady we call the witch too, near the water's edge on the western side - she's quite good with crazy concoctions and stuff. But if you need a proper resupply, you gotta look for a real civilized town.
Is that so? Lucky for you, we got an odd bird living here - call her 'The Real Witch' in this swamp. She knows all about plants, and how to turn them into powerful concoctions...

option.optiontext: I see.

node.text: Ah, it's you again! It occurs to me you never introduced yourself...
node.contextBefore: Happens BEFORE this node: professor's default Thornhill convo

option.optiontext: Yes. I was hoping if you could go over the story behind the Irethorn Pendant again.
Yes, right. I was actually hoping to hear a summary of the main take-aways from your lecture today.
Yes, no. Sadly I must get going. Farewell for now, Professor!

node.text: Oh, right... Hmm, let's see... This was still during a time when Thornhill was but a small village. Two adventurous sorcerer brothers, the Irethorns, decided to settle here in Thornhill. Probably attracted by its name, who knows.

option.optiontext: Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: In any case, their arrival was quickly noticed by a sorceress living in the swamp. She struck her eyes on the elder brother, Arreck. A fact the stories describe the younger brother Arres was initially quite envious of. Back then, as ever, these magi tended to behave like aristocrats - favouring marriages among their own kind.

option.optiontext: Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: And so it was that the elder Irethorn and the Witch of the Swamp were joined together, and for some time everything was well in their world. But then Arreck began to have doubts. Had they rushed to marry in the heat of the moment? Perhaps they weren't such a good match after all. And when the Witch got a temper going, she could turn very dark indeed...

option.optiontext: Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: The final straw came in the form of the cobbler's daughter - pretty beyond belief, it was said. Poor Arreck spent but a night dancing and drinking with her during the Harvest Festival and just so, his heart was stolen.

option.optiontext: Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: Soon after, the honourable, if gullible Arreck sought to break it off with the Witch, to tell her he loved another. But the Witch already knew... In her furious flash of jealousy she had crafted a mirror made of silver, laden with a dark curse.

option.optiontext: Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: The Witch pleaded with Arreck to forget the young vixen, but his mind had been made. So she uncovered her Silvermirror and gazing into it, Arreck's mind became possessed by the Witch.

option.optiontext: Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: When it was done, the Witch sent Arreck to the cobbler's daughter to tell her the most hurtful things. In tears and brokenhearted, she ran to the younger brother, Arres, for help. And after speaking with his brother, it became evident to Arres that his brother's mind was no longer his own.

option.optiontext: Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: So you see, determined to have his brother released, Arres crafted the Irethorn pendant. It was to protect his mind as he confronted the Witch. Regardless, that confrontation was to escalate into tragedy.

option.optiontext: Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: The Witch forced Arreck against Arres - brother fought against brother. The battle ended in Arres' victory, but Arreck was slain. In his grief, Arres struck down the Witch and melted the Silvermirror into a puddle.

option.optiontext: Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: The ordeal naturally left Arres deeply scarred; he became a sombre, solemn man. And the cobbler's daughter... It is said she drowned herself soon after. How youthful love can be so destructive.

option.optiontext: And what do you think became of the missing centre piece of the pendant?
Thank you, Professor. But now I simply must go. Farewell.

node.text: Later on Arres came to marry the next Witch of the Swamp, the prior Witch's apprentice. A much nicer lass than her predecessor. Their union made the Witch something of an unofficial queen to Thornhill, for a time. If I had to guess, the central piece is still there in the swamp, at the Silvermirror Throne.

option.optiontext: A compelling story, indeed. But to change the subject, what would you say were the main take-aways from your lecture today?
Thank you, Professor. But now I simply must go. Farewell.

node.text: So... as I mentioned in my closing remarks, I believe we can draw certain parallels between the time of the Ancients and the recent arrival of the Hydrobor Circle...

option.optiontext: Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: Indeed. Impirillor, as this land was called during the time of the Ancients, was largely untamed. Ahm, inhabited by pockets of tribal and druidic societies, as recent archeological evidence has suggested. Then, of course, its colonisation by the Ancients brought about a cultural renaissance.

option.optiontext: Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: Then, as we know, the Ancients were beset by the Great Pestilence. Umm... little is known about the details, but essentially some kind of a disease, perhaps magical in nature, that swiftly spread to every member of the Ancient's empire. Umm... ultimately lethal, in every instance.

option.optiontext: Hmm... Indeed...
Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: And this left the land uninhabited, in fact, for some time, until its resettlement by the Eastern Civilisations, after which Impirillor became known as the Lordship of Imberthale. And as we know, remained quite the backwater region all the way until the arrival of the Hydrobor Circle...

option.optiontext: Come now, Professor, Imberthale wasn't so bad. There was steady, albeit slow development.
Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: Uhmm... Hmm... I'm not sure I agree with that statement...

option.optiontext: You're from the Bronswind Academy? I know for a fact its founding was sponsored by Lord Rothar Aercrest in his time.

node.text: Well... yes, I suppose that is true but it's a fringe case... more of an exception to the rule. Certainly nothing like the progress stimulated by the Magi of the Hydrobor Circle.

option.optiontext: Oh well, in any case I was actually hoping you'd go over the story behind the Irethorn Pendant again.
Thank you Professor, but I realised I simply must go. Farewell for now!

node.text: Have you come to the shrine to pray...? Do you weep for a lost loved one too...?

option.optiontext: Who did you lose?
I have lost people, yes...

node.text: My dear husband. Not long ago he joined the Haywind militia. Said he wanted to make this land a safer place for everyone, for our children...

He was slain by the bloody looting marauders last week. I wish only that I could give him the honorable burial he deserves - with a ceremonial sword. I couldn't afford to pay Haywind's smith though and he wasn't one to take pity on me.

option.optiontext: I wonder if I can help?
I'm sorry to hear that.

node.text: Oh kind sir, would you? I shan't need anything fancy, a simple copper broadsword would suffice. If you're skilled at the forge, perhaps you could even make one?

option.optiontext: As it happens, I'm carrying a sword I'm willing to spare for you.
I'll see what I can do.
I might, but where would I find a forge?

node.text: I've heard there's a kind man in Timberwell just up the road. He mainly does horseshoes and such, but I'm sure he'd let you use his forge for other purposes if you ask him.

option.optiontext: I'll see what I can do.
Alright, I'll be back later.
What about a forge?
I'll see what I can do.
Alright, I'll be back later.

node.text: Then perhaps you're familiar with my pain. I lost my beloved husband. He joined the Haywind militia, said he wanted to make the land a safer place for everyone, for our children...
You do? You would? Oh thank you for your kindness, stranger! Sadly I don't have the coin to offer you, but please take this ring - it was my husband's keepsake. He won't need it now.

option.optiontext: Thank you, take care now.

node.text: You're back, stranger. Does that mean you have the sword I asked?

option.optiontext: It does. <color=#9C8C77> (offer Abigail a copper broadsword) </color>
I might be able to cast one, but where would I find the forge around here?
Not yet.

node.text: Oh thank you for your kindness, stranger! Simple though it is, I'm sure my husband would have loved this sword. I don't have the coin to offer you, but please take this ring - it was my husband's keepsake. He won't need it anymore.

option.optiontext: Take care now.

node.text: Are you a traveler? Are you headed to Thornhill at some point, by chance?

option.optiontext: Yes, I will end up there at some point.
Sorry, I will not be heading that way.

node.text: My brother - Finnian, moved there ages ago and I have yet to hear from him. Is it possible I can give you a letter and you get it to him? I am in no hurry, but I am worried of what has become of him as it has been so long since he moved away. I'll spare some coin for your troubles if you manage it.

option.optiontext: Sure, I'll seek him out when I get there and get the letter to him.
Sorry, but I have more important things to do other than be a courier.

node.text: Oh thank you so much! If you need directions, just ask! Safe travels!

option.optiontext: Thanks, I'll be sure to find him for you.
So, how do I get to Thornhill?

node.text: Did you find my brother?

option.optiontext: Actually, I forgot what I was supposed to do...
Yes, I did. He gave me a letter to give to you.

node.text: Find my brother, Finnian, in Thornhill and give him my letter. Do you need directions?

option.optiontext: No thank you - off I go.
Yes, directions would be useful.

node.text: Uh, hi?

option.optiontext: Are you Finnian? I was told to give you this letter.
Hi, bye.

node.text: A letter? From who?

option.optiontext: Your sister. She's worried sick about you.

node.text: She sure is a lazy one, isn't she? Can't be fuckin' bothered to walk for a bit to find me herself. Wow, not only that...it's only been a fortnight, yet she acts like it's been years? I swear, she's a damn crazy one! Thats why I left her arse back in Haywind. Anyways, here - I'll write a quick response for you to bring back to her.

Can't believe she gave you this errand. This is outright ridiculous, but I appreciate you helping give her piece of mind. Anyways, here you go - and thanks. Oh, and don't repeat what I said, okay? Seriously.

option.optiontext: No problem.

node.text: Hope all is well, stranger.
Don't forget to get that letter to my sister in Haywind.

option.optiontext: Of course!
Wait, how do I get to Haywind?

node.text: Oh! Thank you so much! I can never repay you for this! Well, I mean beyond some gold. Here you go, and thank you so much!
Thanks again!
